speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument next in 04-1544, Vickie Lynn Marshall v. E. Pierce Marshall. Mr. Richland.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Any exception whatever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So if -- if the contention in the -- in the bankruptcy proceeding is that the will which has been probated by the State probate court is, in fact, not the true will and that under the true will, the bankruptcy estate would get money, you think the bankruptcy court would -- would have jurisdiction to probate the will.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right. Well, I'm willing to -- to move it back. I mean, that's -- that's even harder for you. But let's assume that the will is in probate but has not yet been probated. Do you think the bankruptcy court has jurisdiction to decide which will is the true will?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes or no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What if the rem --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- what if the rem is in another court before the bankruptcy begins? What if the res is within -- is in another court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So even -- even if property is in the custody of another court in the probate proceeding and the bankruptcy proceeding comes later, the bankruptcy proceeding would sweep whatever assets are before the probate court into the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 bankruptcy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you want to stand on this position, Mr. Richland, or do you have a lesser position --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- that -- that might cause you to win? Because -- (Laughter.)

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you did file a challenge to the probate of the will, didn't you, in Texas?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And wasn't the ground for that that it would be inconsistent with the inter vivos trust that you are asserting in the bankruptcy court proceeding?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You like this -- apparently you like this argument, although you say you're miles 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 away from probate. Well, if you want to get into that argument, I guess the strongest argument against keeping it -- for keeping it is bankruptcy jurisdictional statutes shouldn't be interpreted differently than diversity jurisdiction or any other statute, and Markham at least recognizes that there is such a thing as the probate exception and that Congress implicitly adopted it, just as they did the domestic relations exception. Therefore, if we are going to find for you on this ground, we'd have to go back and overrule that case and a lot of other water that's flowed over -- under the bridge or wherever the water flows. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And we ought to take what's given as given, whatever the true meaning of ecclesiastical courts having jurisdiction over certain probate matters or not in the 18th century.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you could say the same thing about diversity jurisdiction, that Congress contemplated that there would be diversity jurisdiction where there was no bankruptcy jurisdiction and no Federal question jurisdiction. I mean, I don't see what that proves.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I'm just saying no more so than -- than when Congress enacted diversity jurisdiction. It intended it to apply, you know, uniformly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's true.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But none -- none of this has to be done for you to win this case, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then I -- I wish we'd stick 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You want to look moderate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Does this case involve anything more than the enforcement of an in personam tort judgment if you are to win?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, it did involve, at least the bankruptcy court thought, the judgment invalidating the inter vivos trust. Was that necessary to the decision? Or am I -- correct me if I'm --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- correct me if I'm wrong about that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I guess what you're going to hear in 5-10 minutes --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- you might as well deal with it now --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- is that the inter vivos -- a -- a claim for a -- the Texas tort of interference with inter vivos gift, according to Texas law, must be brought at the time of the probate proceeding. And for that reason, it is bound up with probate, and for that reason, they didn't have jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Now, let's suppose you're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- suppose they're right about their interpretation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And the strongest case for you on that is?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You said this Court has repeatedly said. So what --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But -- but this case involves a lot more than convenience. It involves a substantial amount of assets that is either going to pass to one person under probate or is not going to be available for passing to that person because of the inter vivos gift. That seems to be more closely related to the core probate matters. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Richland --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- what seems to me to be involved here is what is not uncommon in our Federal system, that is, two proceedings, both dealing with the same or closely related subject matter. It is not infrequent that you have parallel proceedings in Federal court and State court, and then the one that gets finished first -- that judgment is binding on the other. And as I understand it, the probate proceeding 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 concluded first before the district judge reviewed the bankruptcy judge's opinion.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, I'm -- I'm assuming -- and correct me if I'm wrong about this -- that the bankruptcy court makes a proposed opinion. It doesn't become a binding opinion until it's affirmed by the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, if it isn't a core matter. I think you lost on that in the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that was not reviewed by the Ninth Circuit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That would -- that would be the -- if you -- if you're correct about the limits of the probate exception, that issue would be open for review by the Ninth Circuit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Ms. Maynard.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Except if it's a will -- will-specific. In other words, you -- it seems to me you're in for a penny and in for a pound. You recognize the existence of this exception in certain cases, and then you argue against it by saying, well, Congress wrote the statutes broadly. The latter argument disproves your first point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Ms. Maynard, it's my understanding that a lot of this law developed out of the dicta in the Markham case. Do you think the dicta in the Markham case was an accurate description of the prior history?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What do you mean by no jurisdiction to probate a will? Could -- could -- does that exclude the possibility of a bankruptcy court deciding for itself where there are contested wills that in its in view the -- the right -- the valid will is a certain one and that, therefore, the bankruptcy estate includes this fund or doesn't include this fund? Is that probating the will?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, if that isn't probating a will, the exception for probating a will doesn't -- doesn't amount to a hill of beans, does it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, and that this is -- that this is the -- the last will and testament and 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that there is not some other one.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Okay. Now, can -- can the bankruptcy court determine that, that the -- that the proper will and testament of this decedent is this one? We're not probating it. No, no.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We don't pretend to probate it. We're just saying that this happens to be the true will and testament.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Ms. Maynard, you said at one point it's not necessary for you to decide this, but there is vast confusion in the lower courts about the extent of the probate exception. And so I take it that your -- what you began -- what you began with is -- I wrote them down. That's it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And in addition to Markham, what other case of this Court do you think spells out the proper bounds?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You know there are a lot of scholars who think that Markham is the source of most of the confusion, and so that's why I was asking whether you think we should -- to clear up, which you're suggesting we should do, we should reexamine some of that dicta or we should just stick to the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 holding.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: With -- with new dicta of our own? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We could just say whatever its scope is it ain't this. I mean, couldn't we do that?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Maynard. Mr. Brunstad.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Well, is it -- is it correct -- I just want to be sure I follow you -- that they determined that the estate plan was invalid?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But this is all -- this has 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 nothing -- I mean, I -- you have the total differently -- different understanding than I do of this case, and I did read Judge Carter's opinion. I thought that case simply held that because your clients had interfered with an effort by J. Howard to give quite a few millions of dollars to Vickie Marshall -- because of that interference, they had committed the tort of inter vivos interference with a gift, and they had to pay damages. Now, they said a lot of things by way of what the evidence was. Indeed, they did say, as you point out, that your clients forged three pages of the will. But that was simply evidence of their bad intent, and it did not invalidate anything in the probate proceeding, as I read it. Now, what have I said that's not right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm not interested in what he said. I'm interested in what Judge Carter said --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- because that, it seems to me, is -- and what is it that Judge Carter did that was wrong in this respect?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't -- isn't it the case that she can have her claim and she can prove her claim, but she may not be able to collect the judgment unless the living trust is invalid? But that's not what we're litigating here, is it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why does she have to show that is invalid as distinct from showing that another trust, favorable to her, was not created and it was not created because of the tortious conduct of your client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, let me -- let me stop you there because this is something I didn't understand 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 in the brief. You speak of the Texas probate court determining the validity of an estate plan.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I take it the Texas probate court determined the validity of a will here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It determined the validity of -- of a pourover trust. Is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: All right. Isn't it the case that the two Texas determinations can be respected and still, in the Federal court, enter a judgment for tort liability against your client?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's in -- you may be right on that, but that's not what -- what we're here for.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But when you speak of estate plan, you are -- you seem to be talking in global terms; i.e., that there could have been no other disposition of assets by the decedent or on behalf of the decedent except those which the Texas court is recognizing, the trust, the will. Is that what the Texas court does, or does the Texas court say, the will is good, the trust is good?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: In other words, is it preclusive of everything else? That's what I'm getting at.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That -- that sounds to me like a matter of preemption, but -- but -- or not preemption but, you know, res judicata. But just out of curiosity or -- because I think it is relevant, did the Texas probate court have in front of it the documents among the lawyers that the district judge, Judge Carter, relied upon in showing that there was an intent to create the catchall trust?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It had all those documents.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: So why isn't that, as Justice Breyer prefaced his question, an issue of preclusion rather than, as you frame it, an issue of jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why should it? The probate exception is court-created. Congress passed no law that said it. Congress gave the Federal courts jurisdiction in certain categories of cases and expected them to exercise that jurisdiction. Since our jurisdiction is statutory and the probate exception was made up by the courts, shouldn't we interpret it as narrowly as possible, perhaps even do away with it because it lacks any statutory basis?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you say -- you say an -- an estate plan. Most people would think insurance policies are part of their estate plan, and if it's alleged that there was a fraudulent alteration of the beneficiary designation in the insurance policies, is that within the Texas probate court jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, there's -- there's a further irony here in that revocable trusts are always promoted on the grounds that it keeps us out of probate. And now you're -- you're insisting that it has to be in probate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But it isn't probated. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 That's -- it is, indeed, a will substitute. The whole purpose of doing it is to avoid probate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but as Justice Breyer indicated, can't you just, for purposes of understanding the cause of action as asserted by Vickie Marshall here, just say, we will assume the trust is valid, we will assume the will is valid? All we're saying was that there's a tort and he's going to be liable to us in tort.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why? Why? Why? That is to say, what the finding is, is that there was a different matter, a catchall trust, and he told the lawyers, go draw it up so I can give gifts to her, the increase in the value of my property during the 13 months we're 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 married, do it, and they never did it. Now, that seems to have nothing whatsoever to do with the GRAT trust or with the will. It just happens that those are evidentiary, what went on there, of what likely happened with the catchall trust. So I don't see why those are necessary. I don't see why they're more than evidentiary, and I don't see whether or not those are barred, those particular facts have anything to do with this, as far as jurisdiction is concerned. Now, explain to me why I'm wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, that's just one of the things. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Among other things that went on were they hired private detectives to go after her, to keep her from the bed. I mean, you've read that opinion and there are like about 30 things in there. And I grant you that one of those things is the fact that three pages of the living trust, according to the judge, were created after the event of that trust and slipped in without his knowledge. I mean, it's quite a story.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And -- and so I -- but as I read it, there were many, many, many things involved here, and this is just one of them. So how can Texas say that you have to prove this particular one as -- as opposed to proving a lot of others?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but her claim is assume it's been made irrevocable. I just want some money from this guy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That's all she's saying, as I understand it. She -- she can -- as I understand her cause of action, it can proceed on the assumption the will is valid, the -- the trust is valid. Just give me the money that I would have had.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You're arguing a preclusion question, and if the Ninth Circuit thought it had jurisdiction, it could have tested what you say 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 about Texas law. There's no finding in this record of what Texas law is other than what you have just told us, and perhaps you're right and perhaps you're not. But the Ninth Circuit said the Federal door is closed to this probate exception, and that's what we're here to decide.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I think it -- it may be that there's another side to that story. For example, I think the bankruptcy court was heard from first. Arguably, that's binding on the Texas court. Whether the bankruptcy court was right or wrong, it would get full faith and credit. That's one argument. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Another is perhaps you can explain to me how this all started because I thought that it was a claim made against her in the bankruptcy court for defamation. Then the claim that she asserts is a compulsory counterclaim. She has to make it there or she'll lose it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I -- I didn't understand the pleading to say if I have a claim, it would be nondischargeable. I thought he made a claim. He made -- filed a claim for defamation in the bankruptcy proceeding.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: He would have to say I have a claim because the bankruptcy court is not going to decide a hypothetical if he has a claim. He has to at least assert I have a claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It has to be a real claim. It can't be if I have a claim.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Counsel, I don't -- I don't see how the interference with the probate court 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that you're articulating is any greater than the interference in Markham. In Markham, it was a decision by a Federal court that these claimants were not going to claim under the will. Why is -- isn't that even greater than the interference you're complaining of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was it an estate plan or a will?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, you -- you -- you're stretching the probate concept from determining whether the will is valid or invalid and who inherits under the will to also determining what goes into the probate estate, that is, the insurance policies, the trust, and so forth. That to me is -- is something quite different from probating a will. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: No, I don't -- I don't see your -- your logic there. Of course, it protects the succession process, but it does not follow that everything that implicates a succession process falls within the probate exception.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If -- if there had been a joint bank account, the succession would have been determined based on the validity of the joint bank account, and that certainly wouldn't have fallen within the probate exception.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Does -- does Texas law provide that a -- a living trust must be executed and administered with the formalities of a will?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then -- then you have to get beyond our probate exception cases to cover the living trust.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, but she's not -- she's not even going after the assets in this case. She's asserting an in personam claim against the individual. Correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I don't think they're going to impose a constructive trust, are they? All -- all they're going to say is pay her the money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They're going to say it because they make a finding that through a whole variety of various devices, all of which were listed, that J. Howard, who wanted to give her money through something called the catchall trust was prevented in about 15 ways. And even if you're right that there's a Texas finding that those three pages weren't slipped in, well, how do we know? Maybe it was a valid GRAT trust, but if only they hadn't tried to isolate J. Howard from contact with her, J. Howard would have figured out what had happened before he died and he would have told his lawyers, hey, cut this out. Do what I want. Revoke it. But all that is just hypothetical. I'm just using that to show you why I 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 think this is evidentiary not a matter of what the elements of the crime are -- or the elements of the tort are.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's the cite on that that I -- that I need for --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You're saying you can't bring an inter vivos trust -- an inter vivos -- interference with an inter vivos gift action in Texas unless you show that a will, for example, is invalid.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But that -- but that's res judicata. I mean, that -- that isn't necessarily a -- an application of -- of any probate exception.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You say that, but that case doesn't say that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what case do you have that says that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But the mere fact that you have jurisdiction to say something does not mean that if -- if some other court says the same thing first, you won't be bound by that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You -- you are suggesting an extraordinary setup with a State court being able to preclude other courts from dealing with related, not identical matters, and that's just not the way our system works. You can bring duplicative proceedings in different courts. One will finish first and that will bind the others. But I -- I never heard of a State court being able to say, because we are a probate court, that you -- you couldn't bring a tort case someplace else.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The -- the only court I've heard of that can do that is the Federal 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 bankruptcy court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's the definition of an in rem judgment, but she's suing for an in personam judgment an individual, not an estate, just for a plain old money judgment.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Brunstad --

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask you two questions? First, if there were no such animal as the probate exception, would there have been bankruptcy court jurisdiction over your claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So your -- you would prevail even if there were no probate exception in your view.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And my -- my second question is I noticed you quoted from a Minnesota Law Review about 250 cases, and the -- your opponent pointed out that the -- the next sentence of the article said the holdings don't support the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 generalization. And I would just like to ask you, apart from the Markham case, what is the case -- what holding of a case lends the greatest support to your probate exception argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm not asking you to rank them. I don't want a list of cases that have a lot of dicta because some of these cases went off on laches, some went off a lot of different grounds than purely -- than -- some of them don't even mention probate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: By the way, in Texas if you have to go through all this probate stuff and everything, and they want to claim 15 years ago my mother gave a ring to my cousin who stole it, is that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 precluded to bring that tort action when the person who, you know, was supposed to get it finds out about it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So -- so, in other words, if it -- when the guy is 2 years -- 15 years old, he gives a ring to somebody, and now he dies at age 93, and when they find out about that incomplete gift at age 15, nobody can bring a lawsuit anymore. You have to go to the probate court.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Richland, you have 4 minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but did those documents -- did those boxes contain the key documents --

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- about the catchall trust?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The case is submitted.
